What's worse: the politician who profits from contributions from those seeking to gain an advantage or the businessman who offers benefits that resemble bribes? That's one of the key questions voters must answer this year in a presidential contest that offers a pair of unsatisfactory choices. The election is still Hillary Clinton's to lose, but if Donald Trump still has a shot at winning -- and recent polls say as much -- it is because a great many Americans are not as angry about the smart aleck who can game the system as they are about the political establishment.

This dilemma is highlighted by the latest front page New York Times article, which seeks to flesh out the unsavory details about Donald Trump's business career. This one focuses on the well-timed $25,000 contribution the Donald made to the re-election campaign of Florida Attorney General Pam Bondi in 2013. The donation (and a subsequent fundraiser for her that was held at Trump's Mar A-lago resort) arrived not long before her office decided not to join fraud litigation being pursued against Trump University by the state of New York.

That would sound suspicious no matter who was doling out the payola, but coming from Trump, it's hard to accept the claims from Bondi and Trump's campaign about it all being an innocent coincidence. Trump is, as the Times recalls, a man who had been fined for illegal campaign contributions and lobbying. He has testified under oath about his massive donations to New York politicians from whom he sought favors. He's also the guy who has openly boasted in books and speeches about his ability to use his wealth to get what he needs from a system he says is "rigged."

The contribution to Bondi has gotten attention not so much because it was illegal but because it was sloppy. The money came from the Republican candidate's non-profit foundation rather than an account that could make political contributions, and it resulted in another fine for Trump. But like most of his past efforts, it worked. Florida passed on the opportunity to join the suit against the Trump University scam as did other states -- like Texas and California -- whose attorneys general also got generous help from Trump. He may not always pay vendors who provide services to his companies, but he appears to get his money's worth from public servants.

The really interesting thing about this story, and the many others like it, is that it is not having the effect on his campaign that you might have thought it would. While people who are already opposed to Trump view his scams with disgust, the many who support him don't seem to care much. Indeed, while Trump is still likely to lose in November, stories like the Bondi bribe probably won't be the reason.

Why is that?

The first and most obvious reason is that this is an election that pits the proprietor of Trump University against one of the principals at the Clinton Foundation and the owner of the world's most famous home-brew email server. Clinton's reputation has driven her unfavorable poll ratings to the same stratospheric levels as those of Trump and earned her even worse numbers for being honest and trustworthy.

But his good fortune goes beyond the lack of a competitor with a pristine reputation. Trump's GOP primary competitors did not have reputations for lying that could compare to Clinton's, and they did their best to highlight Trump's problems. But Trump triumphed because he could denounce the political system that most of them were part of, portraying himself as someone who had transgressed but now saw the light.

Americans may not be as religious as they once were but they still love a redeemed sinner, and that's what Trump's pose promises. Some may find irony in the moral equivalent of a drunk running on a sobriety platform. But Trump claims that his past ability to work the angles gives him a unique ability to fix it, and that resonates with a lot of voters.

Americans may actually have a sneaking admiration for the person who is an expert at finagling, but they regard those on the inside -- especially those like the Clintons, who entered politics with little money but are now fabulously wealthy -- with far more anger. If stories like the one about Bondi don't sink Trump it's because many voters, if not most, are answering my question by saying that they think the bribed politician is a lot worse than the person offering them cash.

The White House is sensitive to charges that the president is conducting an "apology tour" of the world. And it's true that on Tuesday the president didn't actually apologize in Laos for American actions in the 1960s, but he danced right up to the line.

This is what he said:

Over nine years -- from 1964 to 1973 -- the United States dropped more than two million tons of bombs here in Laos -- more than we dropped on Germany and Japan combined during all of World War II. It made Laos, per person, the most heavily bombed country in history. As one Laotian said, the 'bombs fell like rain.' Villages and entire valleys were obliterated. The ancient Plain of Jars was devastated. Countless civilians were killed. And that conflict was another reminder that, whatever the cause, whatever our intentions, war inflicts a terrible toll, especially on innocent men, women and children. Today, I stand with you in acknowledging the suffering and sacrifices on all sides of that conflict.

He went on to pledge to double U.S. funding, to $90 million a year, to help Laos defuse bombs dropped during the Vietnam War. The problem is a very real one, as I discovered for myself while visiting Laos's Plain of Jars a few months ago -- a tourist site but one where tourists are still warned to look out for unexploded ordnance. Everything Obama said was factual, and there is nothing wrong with his desire to aid Laos -- the U.S. needs as many friends on China's borders as it can find. But his rhetoric was nevertheless one-sided and disappointing.

What was lacking, above all, was any context. Someone who listened to Obama's speech and knew nothing of Laos's history would have been left mystified about why the U.S. dropped bombs "like rain" on that country. Did Americans harbor irrational fear and prejudice of Laotians? Were the Johnson and Nixon administrations motivated by racial prejudice? Perhaps they were simply staffed by psychopaths and war criminals who enjoyed annihilating small countries?

Hardly.

What Obama did not mention was that in 1959, preparatory to its invasion of South Vietnam, North Vietnam invaded Laos in order to establish a major segment of the Ho Chi Minh Trail bringing weapons, supplies, and manpower from North to South. North Vietnam also sponsored and supported with its own troops a Communist insurgency, the Pathet Lao, to overthrow the Royal Government of Laos. The U.S. responded to this Communist aggression -- conducted in violation of the Geneva Accords of 1954 and 1962 -- by providing covert and overt aid to the government of Laos and to Hmong militias who were fighting the Communists. Unlike in South Vietnam, the U.S. did not send combat troops to Laos; instead it relied on the CIA and the Special Forces to fight a "secret war" utilizing Laotians who were determined to resist Communist domination. The most capable American-supported leader was Vang Pao, a Hmong tribesman who was a general in the Lao army. Eventually he led as many as 40,000 guerrillas fighting the Pathet Lao and the North Vietnamese Army.

The U.S. bombing of Laos was conducted in support of Vang Pao and other anti-Communist fighters and as part of a general effort to disrupt the Ho Chi Minh Trail -- the logistics line that enabled aggression against a sovereign state allied with the United States. Those interested in learning more should read my colleague Joshua Kurlantzick's excellent forthcoming book A Great Place to Have a War: America in Laos and the Birth of a Military CIA (out in January from Simon & Schuster).

It is certainly possible to question the utility and even the morality of U.S. bombing in Laos -- but it is highly misleading for any analyst, much less the president of the United States, to criticize the U.S. in a vacuum without noting the actions of the North Vietnamese and the Pathet Lao who killed countless numbers of Laotian civilians, violated Laotian sovereignty, and ultimately overthrew the internationally recognized government of Laos in order to impose a Communist dictatorship. That dictatorship continues to rule to this day, by the way. It has made some economic reforms primarily to encourage tourism, but it remains a dictatorship that is rated "not free" by Freedom House.

To his credit, Obama did speak out about human rights during his trip although in a particularly mealy-mouthed way. He never directly criticized Laos's human-rights record, which is poor. He never highlighted the plight of dissidents or called for democracy. Instead he spoke in oblique terms about the importance of human rights while making clear that they are not very crucial in the U.S.-Laos relationship: "As we do around the world, the United States will continue to speak up on behalf of what we consider universal human rights, including the rights of the people of Laos to express yourselves freely and decide your own future. Yet even as our governments deal candidly with our differences, I believe, as we have shown from Cuba to Burma to Vietnam, the best way to deliver progress for all of our peoples is by closer cooperation between our countries. And that's why, today, the United States and Laos have agreed to a new comprehensive partnership to guide and deepen our relationship for years to come." In other words, while saying he would speak out on behalf of human rights, Obama did not really do that.

I get what Obama is up to here. He thinks the U.S. can exercise more influence today by acknowledging past "misconduct" without directly criticizing the behavior of countries it deals with. The problem is that, in practice, this amounts to kow-towing to dictators from Cuba to Iran and buying into their fiction that the U.S. is guilty of conduct just as bad, if not worse, than what they have done. That simply isn't true, and by shading the truth the president is failing to speak on behalf of the principles upon which the United States was founded-and which have long been our most powerful tool and selling point in international affairs. He is also inadvertently buttressing the dictatorships he is dealing with; now they can turn to their people and say in essence, "Our problems are America's fault-the president of the United States even said so." What we have seen during the two terms of the Obama presidency is that by failing to speak out more robustly on behalf of freedom, the president is not winning any friends; he is simply convincing the world's dictators that he is a patsy who can be pushed around with impunity.

Donald Trump is many things but subtle isn't one of them. While campaigning in Ohio yesterday, he said that Iran "is going to destroy Israel unless I get elected." But if he wins, "then Israel will be just fine." That's a pretty simple formulation and it's one that some friends of the Jewish state are buying. Are they right?

The basic premise of this apocalyptic argument is that the nuclear deal the Obama administration struck with Iran poses an existential threat to the state of Israel. Trump is right about that. The deal makes an Iranian bomb possible in the long term while also enriching the regime and strengthening its ability to support terror and harass Israel via its Hezbollah auxiliaries and Hamas allies.

The question is, what can Trump do about it? Or at least what would he do that Hillary Clinton won't?

The first advantage Trump has is that he enters the Iran debate with clean hands, having never supported President Obama's goal of rapprochement with Tehran. The same cannot be said of Clinton. No, the deal didn't happen on Clinton's watch and it might not have come to pass had she not been replaced by John Kerry at the State Department since he ardent supporter of Obama's approach on Iran. But she still supported the negotiations and the dismal final result.

Clinton says she will zealously enforce the terms of the deal and has made noises -- while keeping as little daylight between herself and President Obama as possible for the purposes of the campaign -- about getting tougher on Iranian behavior in the region.

In contrast to most of the other Republican presidential candidates, Trump never said he would tear up the deal. He has merely held it up as a terrible negotiation in which the U.S. gave up its goals and got little in return. The assumption is that somehow he will attempt to renegotiate or re-impose sanctions to get better terms. But since America's European allies will never go along with such a scenario, short of war, that isn't going to happen. So other than a more robust rhetorical approach to Iran, it's not clear what functional difference there will be between his Iran policy and that of Clinton.

But for all of his justified criticism of the nuclear deal, the rest of Trump's foreign and Middle East policy hints at a less contentious approach to Iran.

As Trump said in his security-policy speech delivered today in Philadelphia, he will "work with any country" provided they are willing to cooperate in the struggle against ISIS. While specifically eschewing regime change in any country in the region, he said "new friendships and partnerships" would be pursued in "this mission."

What does that mean?

It means that Trump is interested in cooperating with Russia and, since he wants the U.S. to shoulder as little responsibility for Middle East security as possible, he seems just as willing as Obama to allow Vladimir Putin a free hand in Syria and other trouble spots. And because Russia is in business with Iran in their joint effort to preserve the Assad regime in Syria a Trump administration would appear to be pursuing the same strategic goals as Obama. Given Trump's disdain for efforts to overturn the theocratic dictatorship in Tehran and his general opposition to U.S. military interventions, friends of the Jewish state may be forgiven for dismissing all this talk about preventing Israel's destruction as mere rhetoric.

Pro-Israel advocates would do well to be just as skeptical of Clinton's claims as a champion of Israel. We don't know whether Trump would pursue renewed negotiations with the Palestinians or pressure Israel to help him create a peace deal. He is probably less interested, however, in a continuation of the same failed policies pursued by both the Clinton and the Obama administration. But if you're judging the two candidates on their ability to enable Israel to survive the threat from Iran, Trump's case seems less impressive in the context of his advocacy for more "realism" -- a word that has always been synonymous with policies that are hostile to Israeli security. Moreover, Israelis know better than to rest their safety on anything other than their own strength.

Put simply, Trump's goals are mutually exclusive. The U.S. can't abandon the region while simultaneously enhancing Israel's security. And no matter how magical your negotiating skills might be, you can't have better relations with Russia and work with Iran against ISIS while also pursuing a tougher policy against the latter's nuclear program.

Yesterday's CNN/ORC poll was a thunderbolt that hit the Clinton campaign right between the eyes. Not only did the survey have Donald Trump leading Hillary Clinton for the first time in the race, it also showed her surpassing Trump's already historically high negatives. If that wasn't bad enough, 50 percent of those polled expressed confidence in the GOP candidate's trustworthiness and honesty while only 35 percent would say the same for Clinton. If, as I noted, these results are repeated in other polls, it will be seen as a turning point in the race. But figuring out whether this is a harbinger of a reversal or a mere statistical outlier depends on your ideas about who will be voting in November.

As Chuck Todd pointed out on MSNBC's Meet the Press Daily yesterday, CNN's poll should be viewed with skepticism because of the sample on which it is based. The population polled by CNN had four percentage points more voters that identified as Republicans than Democrats. More than half of them were whites without a college degree. If that is what the electorate looks like in November then Trump will be poised to win or at least come close.

But that electorate looks nothing like the one that went to the polls in 2012, when only about a third of voters were whites without college degrees and Democrats enjoyed a clear edge. So if you adjust CNN's results for a population that looks more like 2012, Clinton takes the lead by four points. Such a result would still reflect a marked decline in voter trust for Clinton as the drip-drip-drip of stories that highlight her lies about the email scandal continues. Though she may be dropping in the polls, the demographic advantages that the Democrats have carried into the fall among female, minority, and young voters are still there.

If this kind of argument about sample proportions sounds familiar, it should. As I noted in June, Mitt Romney and his supporters had claimed the 2012 polls showing Barack Obama winning were wrong because the samples were too Democratic. I made the same mistake at the time, reasoning that there was no way the electorate would skew as heavily toward minorities and Democrats as it had in 2008. Romney was wrong and so was I. It turned out that, if anything, the polls had underestimated the number of Democrats who would turn out to vote.

Since then, many on the right have claimed that there were millions of missing conservative white voters who stayed home in 2012 rather than cast an unenthusiastic ballot for a moderate like Romney. There isn't much evidence to support this theory, but in order to imagine a Trump victory you'd need a 2016 turnout model composed of more whites (and with those whites being skewed toward those without a college degree) than the one that re-elected Obama in 2012.

Such a scenario is not impossible. Like most voters this year, Democrats are unenthusiastic about their choices. Clinton hasn't the appeal among minorities that the first African-American president did. If Trump wins white voters by a greater percentage than Romney did and if minority turnout doesn't increase or actually goes down, then the billionaire can win.

This would be historic, but it is also unlikely. It is hard to imagine why the fastest growing demographic sectors (particularly Hispanics) would not continue to increase their share of the vote, especially since animosity for Trump seems to be a stand-in for enthusiasm for Obama as an incentive for minorities to turn out. results.title: A Pass For Gaming the System?
results.body:
Campaigns & Elections A Pass For Gaming the System? Jonathan S. Tobin 2016-09-07 Jonathan S. Tobin / Sept. 7, 2016 0Shares Facebook Twitter Google+ Email Print A

What's worse: the politician who profits from contributions from those seeking to gain an advantage or the businessman who offers benefits that resemble bribes? That's one of the key questions voters must answer this year in a presidential contest that offers a pair of unsatisfactory choices. The election is still Hillary Clinton's to lose, but if Donald Trump still has a shot at winning -- and recent polls say as much -- it is because a great many Americans are not as angry about the smart aleck who can game the system as they are about the political establishment.

This dilemma is highlighted by the latest front page New York Times article, which seeks to flesh out the unsavory details about Donald Trump's business career. This one focuses on the well-timed $25,000 contribution the Donald made to the re-election campaign of Florida Attorney General Pam Bondi in 2013. The donation (and a subsequent fundraiser for her that was held at Trump's Mar A-lago resort) arrived not long before her office decided not to join fraud litigation being pursued against Trump University by the state of New York.

That would sound suspicious no matter who was doling out the payola, but coming from Trump, it's hard to accept the claims from Bondi and Trump's campaign about it all being an innocent coincidence. Trump is, as the Times recalls, a man who had been fined for illegal campaign contributions and lobbying. He has testified under oath about his massive donations to New York politicians from whom he sought favors. He's also the guy who has openly boasted in books and speeches about his ability to use his wealth to get what he needs from a system he says is "rigged."

The contribution to Bondi has gotten attention not so much because it was illegal but because it was sloppy. The money came from the Republican candidate's non-profit foundation rather than an account that could make political contributions, and it resulted in another fine for Trump. But like most of his past efforts, it worked. Florida passed on the opportunity to join the suit against the Trump University scam as did other states -- like Texas and California -- whose attorneys general also got generous help from Trump. He may not always pay vendors who provide services to his companies, but he appears to get his money's worth from public servants.

The really interesting thing about this story, and the many others like it, is that it is not having the effect on his campaign that you might have thought it would. While people who are already opposed to Trump view his scams with disgust, the many who support him don't seem to care much. Indeed, while Trump is still likely to lose in November, stories like the Bondi bribe probably won't be the reason.

Why is that?

The first and most obvious reason is that this is an election that pits the proprietor of Trump University against one of the principals at the Clinton Foundation and the owner of the world's most famous home-brew email server. Clinton's reputation has driven her unfavorable poll ratings to the same stratospheric levels as those of Trump and earned her even worse numbers for being honest and trustworthy.

But his good fortune goes beyond the lack of a competitor with a pristine reputation. Trump's GOP primary competitors did not have reputations for lying that could compare to Clinton's, and they did their best to highlight Trump's problems. But Trump triumphed because he could denounce the political system that most of them were part of, portraying himself as someone who had transgressed but now saw the light.

Americans may not be as religious as they once were but they still love a redeemed sinner, and that's what Trump's pose promises. Some may find irony in the moral equivalent of a drunk running on a sobriety platform. But Trump claims that his past ability to work the angles gives him a unique ability to fix it, and that resonates with a lot of voters.

Americans may actually have a sneaking admiration for the person who is an expert at finagling, but they regard those on the inside -- especially those like the Clintons, who entered politics with little money but are now fabulously wealthy -- with far more anger. If stories like the one about Bondi don't sink Trump it's because many voters, if not most, are answering my question by saying that they think the bribed politician is a lot worse than the person offering them cash.

The White House is sensitive to charges that the president is conducting an "apology tour" of the world. And it's true that on Tuesday the president didn't actually apologize in Laos for American actions in the 1960s, but he danced right up to the line.

This is what he said:

Over nine years -- from 1964 to 1973 -- the United States dropped more than two million tons of bombs here in Laos -- more than we dropped on Germany and Japan combined during all of World War II. It made Laos, per person, the most heavily bombed country in history. As one Laotian said, the 'bombs fell like rain.' Villages and entire valleys were obliterated. The ancient Plain of Jars was devastated. Countless civilians were killed. And that conflict was another reminder that, whatever the cause, whatever our intentions, war inflicts a terrible toll, especially on innocent men, women and children. Today, I stand with you in acknowledging the suffering and sacrifices on all sides of that conflict.

He went on to pledge to double U.S. funding, to $90 million a year, to help Laos defuse bombs dropped during the Vietnam War. The problem is a very real one, as I discovered for myself while visiting Laos's Plain of Jars a few months ago -- a tourist site but one where tourists are still warned to look out for unexploded ordnance. Everything Obama said was factual, and there is nothing wrong with his desire to aid Laos -- the U.S. needs as many friends on China's borders as it can find. But his rhetoric was nevertheless one-sided and disappointing.

What was lacking, above all, was any context. Someone who listened to Obama's speech and knew nothing of Laos's history would have been left mystified about why the U.S. dropped bombs "like rain" on that country. Did Americans harbor irrational fear and prejudice of Laotians? Were the Johnson and Nixon administrations motivated by racial prejudice? Perhaps they were simply staffed by psychopaths and war criminals who enjoyed annihilating small countries?

Hardly.

What Obama did not mention was that in 1959, preparatory to its invasion of South Vietnam, North Vietnam invaded Laos in order to establish a major segment of the Ho Chi Minh Trail bringing weapons, supplies, and manpower from North to South. North Vietnam also sponsored and supported with its own troops a Communist insurgency, the Pathet Lao, to overthrow the Royal Government of Laos. The U.S. responded to this Communist aggression -- conducted in violation of the Geneva Accords of 1954 and 1962 -- by providing covert and overt aid to the government of Laos and to Hmong militias who were fighting the Communists. Unlike in South Vietnam, the U.S. did not send combat troops to Laos; instead it relied on the CIA and the Special Forces to fight a "secret war" utilizing Laotians who were determined to resist Communist domination. The most capable American-supported leader was Vang Pao, a Hmong tribesman who was a general in the Lao army. Eventually he led as many as 40,000 guerrillas fighting the Pathet Lao and the North Vietnamese Army.

The U.S. bombing of Laos was conducted in support of Vang Pao and other anti-Communist fighters and as part of a general effort to disrupt the Ho Chi Minh Trail -- the logistics line that enabled aggression against a sovereign state allied with the United States. Those interested in learning more should read my colleague Joshua Kurlantzick's excellent forthcoming book A Great Place to Have a War: America in Laos and the Birth of a Military CIA (out in January from Simon & Schuster).

It is certainly possible to question the utility and even the morality of U.S. bombing in Laos -- but it is highly misleading for any analyst, much less the president of the United States, to criticize the U.S. in a vacuum without noting the actions of the North Vietnamese and the Pathet Lao who killed countless numbers of Laotian civilians, violated Laotian sovereignty, and ultimately overthrew the internationally recognized government of Laos in order to impose a Communist dictatorship. That dictatorship continues to rule to this day, by the way. It has made some economic reforms primarily to encourage tourism, but it remains a dictatorship that is rated "not free" by Freedom House.

To his credit, Obama did speak out about human rights during his trip although in a particularly mealy-mouthed way. He never directly criticized Laos's human-rights record, which is poor. He never highlighted the plight of dissidents or called for democracy. Instead he spoke in oblique terms about the importance of human rights while making clear that they are not very crucial in the U.S.-Laos relationship: "As we do around the world, the United States will continue to speak up on behalf of what we consider universal human rights, including the rights of the people of Laos to express yourselves freely and decide your own future. Yet even as our governments deal candidly with our differences, I believe, as we have shown from Cuba to Burma to Vietnam, the best way to deliver progress for all of our peoples is by closer cooperation between our countries. And that's why, today, the United States and Laos have agreed to a new comprehensive partnership to guide and deepen our relationship for years to come." In other words, while saying he would speak out on behalf of human rights, Obama did not really do that.

I get what Obama is up to here. He thinks the U.S. can exercise more influence today by acknowledging past "misconduct" without directly criticizing the behavior of countries it deals with. The problem is that, in practice, this amounts to kow-towing to dictators from Cuba to Iran and buying into their fiction that the U.S. is guilty of conduct just as bad, if not worse, than what they have done. That simply isn't true, and by shading the truth the president is failing to speak on behalf of the principles upon which the United States was founded-and which have long been our most powerful tool and selling point in international affairs. He is also inadvertently buttressing the dictatorships he is dealing with; now they can turn to their people and say in essence, "Our problems are America's fault-the president of the United States even said so." What we have seen during the two terms of the Obama presidency is that by failing to speak out more robustly on behalf of freedom, the president is not winning any friends; he is simply convincing the world's dictators that he is a patsy who can be pushed around with impunity.

Donald Trump is many things but subtle isn't one of them. While campaigning in Ohio yesterday, he said that Iran "is going to destroy Israel unless I get elected." But if he wins, "then Israel will be just fine." That's a pretty simple formulation and it's one that some friends of the Jewish state are buying. Are they right?

The basic premise of this apocalyptic argument is that the nuclear deal the Obama administration struck with Iran poses an existential threat to the state of Israel. Trump is right about that. The deal makes an Iranian bomb possible in the long term while also enriching the regime and strengthening its ability to support terror and harass Israel via its Hezbollah auxiliaries and Hamas allies.

The question is, what can Trump do about it? Or at least what would he do that Hillary Clinton won't?

The first advantage Trump has is that he enters the Iran debate with clean hands, having never supported President Obama's goal of rapprochement with Tehran. The same cannot be said of Clinton. No, the deal didn't happen on Clinton's watch and it might not have come to pass had she not been replaced by John Kerry at the State Department since he ardent supporter of Obama's approach on Iran. But she still supported the negotiations and the dismal final result.

Clinton says she will zealously enforce the terms of the deal and has made noises -- while keeping as little daylight between herself and President Obama as possible for the purposes of the campaign -- about getting tougher on Iranian behavior in the region.

In contrast to most of the other Republican presidential candidates, Trump never said he would tear up the deal. He has merely held it up as a terrible negotiation in which the U.S. gave up its goals and got little in return. The assumption is that somehow he will attempt to renegotiate or re-impose sanctions to get better terms. But since America's European allies will never go along with such a scenario, short of war, that isn't going to happen. So other than a more robust rhetorical approach to Iran, it's not clear what functional difference there will be between his Iran policy and that of Clinton.

But for all of his justified criticism of the nuclear deal, the rest of Trump's foreign and Middle East policy hints at a less contentious approach to Iran.

As Trump said in his security-policy speech delivered today in Philadelphia, he will "work with any country" provided they are willing to cooperate in the struggle against ISIS. While specifically eschewing regime change in any country in the region, he said "new friendships and partnerships" would be pursued in "this mission."

What does that mean?

It means that Trump is interested in cooperating with Russia and, since he wants the U.S. to shoulder as little responsibility for Middle East security as possible, he seems just as willing as Obama to allow Vladimir Putin a free hand in Syria and other trouble spots. And because Russia is in business with Iran in their joint effort to preserve the Assad regime in Syria a Trump administration would appear to be pursuing the same strategic goals as Obama. Given Trump's disdain for efforts to overturn the theocratic dictatorship in Tehran and his general opposition to U.S. military interventions, friends of the Jewish state may be forgiven for dismissing all this talk about preventing Israel's destruction as mere rhetoric.

Pro-Israel advocates would do well to be just as skeptical of Clinton's claims as a champion of Israel. We don't know whether Trump would pursue renewed negotiations with the Palestinians or pressure Israel to help him create a peace deal. He is probably less interested, however, in a continuation of the same failed policies pursued by both the Clinton and the Obama administration. But if you're judging the two candidates on their ability to enable Israel to survive the threat from Iran, Trump's case seems less impressive in the context of his advocacy for more "realism" -- a word that has always been synonymous with policies that are hostile to Israeli security. Moreover, Israelis know better than to rest their safety on anything other than their own strength.

Put simply, Trump's goals are mutually exclusive. The U.S. can't abandon the region while simultaneously enhancing Israel's security. And no matter how magical your negotiating skills might be, you can't have better relations with Russia and work with Iran against ISIS while also pursuing a tougher policy against the latter's nuclear program.

Yesterday's CNN/ORC poll was a thunderbolt that hit the Clinton campaign right between the eyes. Not only did the survey have Donald Trump leading Hillary Clinton for the first time in the race, it also showed her surpassing Trump's already historically high negatives. If that wasn't bad enough, 50 percent of those polled expressed confidence in the GOP candidate's trustworthiness and honesty while only 35 percent would say the same for Clinton. If, as I noted, these results are repeated in other polls, it will be seen as a turning point in the race. But figuring out whether this is a harbinger of a reversal or a mere statistical outlier depends on your ideas about who will be voting in November.

As Chuck Todd pointed out on MSNBC's Meet the Press Daily yesterday, CNN's poll should be viewed with skepticism because of the sample on which it is based. The population polled by CNN had four percentage points more voters that identified as Republicans than Democrats. More than half of them were whites without a college degree. If that is what the electorate looks like in November then Trump will be poised to win or at least come close.

But that electorate looks nothing like the one that went to the polls in 2012, when only about a third of voters were whites without college degrees and Democrats enjoyed a clear edge. So if you adjust CNN's results for a population that looks more like 2012, Clinton takes the lead by four points. Such a result would still reflect a marked decline in voter trust for Clinton as the drip-drip-drip of stories that highlight her lies about the email scandal continues. Though she may be dropping in the polls, the demographic advantages that the Democrats have carried into the fall among female, minority, and young voters are still there.

If this kind of argument about sample proportions sounds familiar, it should. As I noted in June, Mitt Romney and his supporters had claimed the 2012 polls showing Barack Obama winning were wrong because the samples were too Democratic. I made the same mistake at the time, reasoning that there was no way the electorate would skew as heavily toward minorities and Democrats as it had in 2008. Romney was wrong and so was I. It turned out that, if anything, the polls had underestimated the number of Democrats who would turn out to vote.

Since then, many on the right have claimed that there were millions of missing conservative white voters who stayed home in 2012 rather than cast an unenthusiastic ballot for a moderate like Romney. There isn't much evidence to support this theory, but in order to imagine a Trump victory you'd need a 2016 turnout model composed of more whites (and with those whites being skewed toward those without a college degree) than the one that re-elected Obama in 2012.

Such a scenario is not impossible. Like most voters this year, Democrats are unenthusiastic about their choices. Clinton hasn't the appeal among minorities that the first African-American president did. If Trump wins white voters by a greater percentage than Romney did and if minority turnout doesn't increase or actually goes down, then the billionaire can win.

This would be historic, but it is also unlikely. It is hard to imagine why the fastest growing demographic sectors (particularly Hispanics) would not continue to increase their share of the vote, especially since animosity for Trump seems to be a stand-in for enthusiasm for Obama as an incentive for minorities to turn out. And since Trump is losing among college-educated whites -- a group Romney won by double digits -- the prospect of the GOP getting a higher share of the white vote requires the miraculous appearance of those missing millions of white working-class voters who have never voted and who may not actually exist.

Both sides dismiss unfavorable polls and laud those who tell them what they want to hear. But unless Trump's presence on the ballot can transform the electorate into something that doesn't seem to exist, his supporters' optimism is unfounded.

A month ago, Donald Trump openly declared that he believed the election would be rigged against him. But now Trump and his followers aren't the only ones worrying about the integrity of the election. The Russian hacking of the Democratic National Committee raises serious questions about just how far Moscow would go to help Trump and defeat Hillary Clinton because of Trump's open advocacy of appeasement of the Vladimir Putin regime. Add to that other legitimate concerns that have been discussed in the media about the security of electronic voting and reporting systems and you've got the makings of a terrible controversy if, as today's national polls indicate, the presidential election turns out to be close.

Trump's talk of a rigged election fit in neatly with his dark vision of America as a corrupt nation in decline. For those who truly believe the country is on the verge of collapse, it doesn't take much of a leap of imagination to think the system's malignant puppeteers will stop at nothing to prevent the Trump revolution. For months, Trump's alt-right cheering section at Breitbart and elsewhere on the Internet have been stoking his followers' fears that their hero would be cheated of the presidency. That's why some tortured souls imagine President Obama will either suspend elections or somehow thwart the will of "we the people" this fall.

That's crazy stuff, but given the fact that American popular culture has been endlessly feeding audiences such paranoid scenarios in films and TV shows since the 1960s, why should we be surprised if some people -- on both the left and the right -- are ready to buy into the notion that life will somehow imitate art in 2016?

But while, as our Max Boot correctly stated yesterday, the Obama administration must send a strong message to Russia to make them understand we won't tolerate any interference, we must at the same time recognize that there's nothing new about fears of cheating in American politics.

One of the most disingenuous arguments that Democrats have used against voter ID laws is that there is no such thing as voter fraud. In order to accept this claim, you'd have to forget much of American political history as well as everything we know about human nature. Attempts to rig elections are as old as the republic itself. Most pundits rightly disparaged Trump's comments about rigged elections. But the fact that they were uttered in Pennsylvania stems from by no means from unreasonable Republican allegations that Democrats have been using their minority voter stronghold in Philadelphia to pad their totals.

But let's also remember that the left has its own myths about cheating. Many Democrats remain convinced the 2000 election was stolen in Florida even if the evidence showed that Bush actually won the state, albeit because of a confusing ballot in one county that Republicans had no hand in creating. Liberals also made misleading claims about electronic voting machines being rigged to help Bush in 2004 and about his win in Ohio being the result of illegal manipulation.

These disputes are only remembered if the outcome of an election is close. Every time a presidential election is won by a narrow margin, claims of fraud arise. More to the point, those charges have special resonance when the two parties view each other's candidates as illegitimate. The Internet and social media have made this worse.

If worries about fraud are louder than ever this year it is because we have the two most unpopular presidential candidates in our modern history. Many Americans think Trump to be not merely wrong but unfit for the presidency. As the most recent polls demonstrate, just as many feel the same way about Hillary Clinton. No matter who prevails, the winner is going to be considered illegitimate by much of the country. Republicans may have thought John Kennedy's camp stole the 1960 election and some Democrats may have thought the same thing about Bush in 2000 and 2004. But those arguments will be nothing when compared to what will greet the election of either Trump or Clinton this year if the result is close.

Whether or not the Russians do their worst or any other bad actor tries to cook the results, those who care about democracy must hope for a decisive win by either side. Anything else will only feed the perfect storm of paranoia and cynicism that has migrated from the fever swamps of American politics to the mainstream in recent years.

On this week's podcast, Abe Greenwald and I survey the bad polling news for Hillary Clinton in the wake of the release of her FBI interview and what a race between two extremely unpopular people might mean in November. We wonder at Donald Trump's insistence on enlarging a military he does not wish to use, and wonder how he can reconcile all that with his promise to destroy ISIS. And we do not forget how the president was dissed in Asia. Give a listen.

The White House is sensitive to charges that the president is conducting an "apology tour" of the world. And it's true that on Tuesday the president didn't actually apologize in Laos for American actions in the 1960s, but he danced right up to the line.

This is what he said:

Over nine years -- from 1964 to 1973 -- the United States dropped more than two million tons of bombs here in Laos -- more than we dropped on Germany and Japan combined during all of World War II. It made Laos, per person, the most heavily bombed country in history. As one Laotian said, the 'bombs fell like rain.' Villages and entire valleys were obliterated. The ancient Plain of Jars was devastated. Countless civilians were killed. And that conflict was another reminder that, whatever the cause, whatever our intentions, war inflicts a terrible toll, especially on innocent men, women and children. Today, I stand with you in acknowledging the suffering and sacrifices on all sides of that conflict.

He went on to pledge to double U.S. funding, to $90 million a year, to help Laos defuse bombs dropped during the Vietnam War. The problem is a very real one, as I discovered for myself while visiting Laos's Plain of Jars a few months ago -- a tourist site but one where tourists are still warned to look out for unexploded ordnance. Everything Obama said was factual, and there is nothing wrong with his desire to aid Laos -- the U.S. needs as many friends on China's borders as it can find. But his rhetoric was nevertheless one-sided and disappointing.

What was lacking, above all, was any context. Someone who listened to Obama's speech and knew nothing of Laos's history would have been left mystified about why the U.S. dropped bombs "like rain" on that country. Did Americans harbor irrational fear and prejudice of Laotians? Were the Johnson and Nixon administrations motivated by racial prejudice? Perhaps they were simply staffed by psychopaths and war criminals who enjoyed annihilating small countries?

Hardly.

What Obama did not mention was that in 1959, preparatory to its invasion of South Vietnam, North Vietnam invaded Laos in order to establish a major segment of the Ho Chi Minh Trail bringing weapons, supplies, and manpower from North to South. North Vietnam also sponsored and supported with its own troops a Communist insurgency, the Pathet Lao, to overthrow the Royal Government of Laos. The U.S. responded to this Communist aggression -- conducted in violation of the Geneva Accords of 1954 and 1962 -- by providing covert and overt aid to the government of Laos and to Hmong militias who were fighting the Communists. Unlike in South Vietnam, the U.S. did not send combat troops to Laos; instead it relied on the CIA and the Special Forces to fight a "secret war" utilizing Laotians who were determined to resist Communist domination. The most capable American-supported leader was Vang Pao, a Hmong tribesman who was a general in the Lao army. Eventually he led as many as 40,000 guerrillas fighting the Pathet Lao and the North Vietnamese Army.

The U.S. bombing of Laos was conducted in support of Vang Pao and other anti-Communist fighters and as part of a general effort to disrupt the Ho Chi Minh Trail -- the logistics line that enabled aggression against a sovereign state allied with the United States. Those interested in learning more should read my colleague Joshua Kurlantzick's excellent forthcoming book A Great Place to Have a War: America in Laos and the Birth of a Military CIA (out in January from Simon & Schuster).

It is certainly possible to question the utility and even the morality of U.S. bombing in Laos -- but it is highly misleading for any analyst, much less the president of the United States, to criticize the U.S. in a vacuum without noting the actions of the North Vietnamese and the Pathet Lao who killed countless numbers of Laotian civilians, violated Laotian sovereignty, and ultimately overthrew the internationally recognized government of Laos in order to impose a Communist dictatorship. That dictatorship continues to rule to this day, by the way. It has made some economic reforms primarily to encourage tourism, but it remains a dictatorship that is rated "not free" by Freedom House.

To his credit, Obama did speak out about human rights during his trip although in a particularly mealy-mouthed way. He never directly criticized Laos's human-rights record, which is poor. He never highlighted the plight of dissidents or called for democracy. Instead he spoke in oblique terms about the importance of human rights while making clear that they are not very crucial in the U.S.-Laos relationship: "As we do around the world, the United States will continue to speak up on behalf of what we consider universal human rights, including the rights of the people of Laos to express yourselves freely and decide your own future. Yet even as our governments deal candidly with our differences, I believe, as we have shown from Cuba to Burma to Vietnam, the best way to deliver progress for all of our peoples is by closer cooperation between our countries. And that's why, today, the United States and Laos have agreed to a new comprehensive partnership to guide and deepen our relationship for years to come." In other words, while saying he would speak out on behalf of human rights, Obama did not really do that.

I get what Obama is up to here. He thinks the U.S. can exercise more influence today by acknowledging past "misconduct" without directly criticizing the behavior of countries it deals with. The problem is that, in practice, this amounts to kow-towing to dictators from Cuba to Iran and buying into their fiction that the U.S. is guilty of conduct just as bad, if not worse, than what they have done. That simply isn't true, and by shading the truth the president is failing to speak on behalf of the principles upon which the United States was founded-and which have long been our most powerful tool and selling point in international affairs. He is also inadvertently buttressing the dictatorships he is dealing with; now they can turn to their people and say in essence, "Our problems are America's fault-the president of the United States even said so." What we have seen during the two terms of the Obama presidency is that by failing to speak out more robustly on behalf of freedom, the president is not winning any friends; he is simply convincing the world's dictators that he is a patsy who can be pushed around with impunity.

Donald Trump is many things but subtle isn't one of them. While campaigning in Ohio yesterday, he said that Iran "is going to destroy Israel unless I get elected." But if he wins, "then Israel will be just fine." That's a pretty simple formulation and it's one that some friends of the Jewish state are buying. Are they right?

The basic premise of this apocalyptic argument is that the nuclear deal the Obama administration struck with Iran poses an existential threat to the state of Israel. Trump is right about that. The deal makes an Iranian bomb possible in the long term while also enriching the regime and strengthening its ability to support terror and harass Israel via its Hezbollah auxiliaries and Hamas allies.

The question is, what can Trump do about it? Or at least what would he do that Hillary Clinton won't?

The first advantage Trump has is that he enters the Iran debate with clean hands, having never supported President Obama's goal of rapprochement with Tehran. The same cannot be said of Clinton. No, the deal didn't happen on Clinton's watch and it might not have come to pass had she not been replaced by John Kerry at the State Department since he ardent supporter of Obama's approach on Iran. But she still supported the negotiations and the dismal final result.

Clinton says she will zealously enforce the terms of the deal and has made noises -- while keeping as little daylight between herself and President Obama as possible for the purposes of the campaign -- about getting tougher on Iranian behavior in the region.

In contrast to most of the other Republican presidential candidates, Trump never said he would tear up the deal. He has merely held it up as a terrible negotiation in which the U.S. gave up its goals and got little in return. The assumption is that somehow he will attempt to renegotiate or re-impose sanctions to get better terms. But since America's European allies will never go along with such a scenario, short of war, that isn't going to happen. So other than a more robust rhetorical approach to Iran, it's not clear what functional difference there will be between his Iran policy and that of Clinton.

But for all of his justified criticism of the nuclear deal, the rest of Trump's foreign and Middle East policy hints at a less contentious approach to Iran.

As Trump said in his security-policy speech delivered today in Philadelphia, he will "work with any country" provided they are willing to cooperate in the struggle against ISIS. While specifically eschewing regime change in any country in the region, he said "new friendships and partnerships" would be pursued in "this mission."

What does that mean?

It means that Trump is interested in cooperating with Russia and, since he wants the U.S. to shoulder as little responsibility for Middle East security as possible, he seems just as willing as Obama to allow Vladimir Putin a free hand in Syria and other trouble spots. And because Russia is in business with Iran in their joint effort to preserve the Assad regime in Syria a Trump administration would appear to be pursuing the same strategic goals as Obama. Given Trump's disdain for efforts to overturn the theocratic dictatorship in Tehran and his general opposition to U.S. military interventions, friends of the Jewish state may be forgiven for dismissing all this talk about preventing Israel's destruction as mere rhetoric.

Pro-Israel advocates would do well to be just as skeptical of Clinton's claims as a champion of Israel. We don't know whether Trump would pursue renewed negotiations with the Palestinians or pressure Israel to help him create a peace deal. He is probably less interested, however, in a continuation of the same failed policies pursued by both the Clinton and the Obama administration. But if you're judging the two candidates on their ability to enable Israel to survive the threat from Iran, Trump's case seems less impressive in the context of his advocacy for more "realism" -- a word that has always been synonymous with policies that are hostile to Israeli security. Moreover, Israelis know better than to rest their safety on anything other than their own strength.

Put simply, Trump's goals are mutually exclusive. The U.S. can't abandon the region while simultaneously enhancing Israel's security. And no matter how magical your negotiating skills might be, you can't have better relations with Russia and work with Iran against ISIS while also pursuing a tougher policy against the latter's nuclear program.

Yesterday's CNN/ORC poll was a thunderbolt that hit the Clinton campaign right between the eyes. Not only did the survey have Donald Trump leading Hillary Clinton for the first time in the race, it also showed her surpassing Trump's already historically high negatives. If that wasn't bad enough, 50 percent of those polled expressed confidence in the GOP candidate's trustworthiness and honesty while only 35 percent would say the same for Clinton. If, as I noted, these results are repeated in other polls, it will be seen as a turning point in the race. But figuring out whether this is a harbinger of a reversal or a mere statistical outlier depends on your ideas about who will be voting in November.

As Chuck Todd pointed out on MSNBC's Meet the Press Daily yesterday, CNN's poll should be viewed with skepticism because of the sample on which it is based. The population polled by CNN had four percentage points more voters that identified as Republicans than Democrats. More than half of them were whites without a college degree. If that is what the electorate looks like in November then Trump will be poised to win or at least come close.

But that electorate looks nothing like the one that went to the polls in 2012, when only about a third of voters were whites without college degrees and Democrats enjoyed a clear edge. So if you adjust CNN's results for a population that looks more like 2012, Clinton takes the lead by four points. Such a result would still reflect a marked decline in voter trust for Clinton as the drip-drip-drip of stories that highlight her lies about the email scandal continues. Though she may be dropping in the polls, the demographic advantages that the Democrats have carried into the fall among female, minority, and young voters are still there.

If this kind of argument about sample proportions sounds familiar, it should. As I noted in June, Mitt Romney and his supporters had claimed the 2012 polls showing Barack Obama winning were wrong because the samples were too Democratic. I made the same mistake at the time, reasoning that there was no way the electorate would skew as heavily toward minorities and Democrats as it had in 2008. Romney was wrong and so was I. It turned out that, if anything, the polls had underestimated the number of Democrats who would turn out to vote.

Since then, many on the right have claimed that there were millions of missing conservative white voters who stayed home in 2012 rather than cast an unenthusiastic ballot for a moderate like Romney. There isn't much evidence to support this theory, but in order to imagine a Trump victory you'd need a 2016 turnout model composed of more whites (and with those whites being skewed toward those without a college degree) than the one that re-elected Obama in 2012.

Such a scenario is not impossible. Like most voters this year, Democrats are unenthusiastic about their choices. Clinton hasn't the appeal among minorities that the first African-American president did. If Trump wins white voters by a greater percentage than Romney did and if minority turnout doesn't increase or actually goes down, then the billionaire can win.

This would be historic, but it is also unlikely. It is hard to imagine why the fastest growing demographic sectors (particularly Hispanics) would not continue to increase their share of the vote, especially since animosity for Trump seems to be a stand-in for enthusiasm for Obama as an incentive for minorities to turn out. And since Trump is losing among college-educated whites -- a group Romney won by double digits -- the prospect of the GOP getting a higher share of the white vote requires the miraculous appearance of those missing millions of white working-class voters who have never voted and who may not actually exist.

Both sides dismiss unfavorable polls and laud those who tell them what they want to hear. But unless Trump's presence on the ballot can transform the electorate into something that doesn't seem to exist, his supporters' optimism is unfounded.

A month ago, Donald Trump openly declared that he believed the election would be rigged against him. But now Trump and his followers aren't the only ones worrying about the integrity of the election. The Russian hacking of the Democratic National Committee raises serious questions about just how far Moscow would go to help Trump and defeat Hillary Clinton because of Trump's open advocacy of appeasement of the Vladimir Putin regime. Add to that other legitimate concerns that have been discussed in the media about the security of electronic voting and reporting systems and you've got the makings of a terrible controversy if, as today's national polls indicate, the presidential election turns out to be close.

Trump's talk of a rigged election fit in neatly with his dark vision of America as a corrupt nation in decline. For those who truly believe the country is on the verge of collapse, it doesn't take much of a leap of imagination to think the system's malignant puppeteers will stop at nothing to prevent the Trump revolution. For months, Trump's alt-right cheering section at Breitbart and elsewhere on the Internet have been stoking his followers' fears that their hero would be cheated of the presidency. That's why some tortured souls imagine President Obama will either suspend elections or somehow thwart the will of "we the people" this fall.

That's crazy stuff, but given the fact that American popular culture has been endlessly feeding audiences such paranoid scenarios in films and TV shows since the 1960s, why should we be surprised if some people -- on both the left and the right -- are ready to buy into the notion that life will somehow imitate art in 2016?

But while, as our Max Boot correctly stated yesterday, the Obama administration must send a strong message to Russia to make them understand we won't tolerate any interference, we must at the same time recognize that there's nothing new about fears of cheating in American politics.

One of the most disingenuous arguments that Democrats have used against voter ID laws is that there is no such thing as voter fraud. In order to accept this claim, you'd have to forget much of American political history as well as everything we know about human nature. Attempts to rig elections are as old as the republic itself. Most pundits rightly disparaged Trump's comments about rigged elections. But the fact that they were uttered in Pennsylvania stems from by no means from unreasonable Republican allegations that Democrats have been using their minority voter stronghold in Philadelphia to pad their totals.

But let's also remember that the left has its own myths about cheating. Many Democrats remain convinced the 2000 election was stolen in Florida even if the evidence showed that Bush actually won the state, albeit because of a confusing ballot in one county that Republicans had no hand in creating. Liberals also made misleading claims about electronic voting machines being rigged to help Bush in 2004 and about his win in Ohio being the result of illegal manipulation.

These disputes are only remembered if the outcome of an election is close. Every time a presidential election is won by a narrow margin, claims of fraud arise. More to the point, those charges have special resonance when the two parties view each other's candidates as illegitimate. The Internet and social media have made this worse.

If worries about fraud are louder than ever this year it is because we have the two most unpopular presidential candidates in our modern history. Many Americans think Trump to be not merely wrong but unfit for the presidency. As the most recent polls demonstrate, just as many feel the same way about Hillary Clinton. No matter who prevails, the winner is going to be considered illegitimate by much of the country. Republicans may have thought John Kennedy's camp stole the 1960 election and some Democrats may have thought the same thing about Bush in 2000 and 2004. But those arguments will be nothing when compared to what will greet the election of either Trump or Clinton this year if the result is close.

Whether or not the Russians do their worst or any other bad actor tries to cook the results, those who care about democracy must hope for a decisive win by either side. Anything else will only feed the perfect storm of paranoia and cynicism that has migrated from the fever swamps of American politics to the mainstream in recent years.

results.body:
Asia Another Obama Apology Tour? Max Boot 2016-09-07 Max Boot / Sept. 7, 2016 0Shares Facebook Twitter Google+ Email Print A

The White House is sensitive to charges that the president is conducting an "apology tour" of the world. And it's true that on Tuesday the president didn't actually apologize in Laos for American actions in the 1960s, but he danced right up to the line.

This is what he said:

Over nine years -- from 1964 to 1973 -- the United States dropped more than two million tons of bombs here in Laos -- more than we dropped on Germany and Japan combined during all of World War II. It made Laos, per person, the most heavily bombed country in history. As one Laotian said, the 'bombs fell like rain.' Villages and entire valleys were obliterated. The ancient Plain of Jars was devastated. Countless civilians were killed. And that conflict was another reminder that, whatever the cause, whatever our intentions, war inflicts a terrible toll, especially on innocent men, women and children. Today, I stand with you in acknowledging the suffering and sacrifices on all sides of that conflict.

He went on to pledge to double U.S. funding, to $90 million a year, to help Laos defuse bombs dropped during the Vietnam War. The problem is a very real one, as I discovered for myself while visiting Laos's Plain of Jars a few months ago -- a tourist site but one where tourists are still warned to look out for unexploded ordnance. Everything Obama said was factual, and there is nothing wrong with his desire to aid Laos -- the U.S. needs as many friends on China's borders as it can find. But his rhetoric was nevertheless one-sided and disappointing.

What was lacking, above all, was any context. Someone who listened to Obama's speech and knew nothing of Laos's history would have been left mystified about why the U.S. dropped bombs "like rain" on that country. Did Americans harbor irrational fear and prejudice of Laotians? Were the Johnson and Nixon administrations motivated by racial prejudice? Perhaps they were simply staffed by psychopaths and war criminals who enjoyed annihilating small countries?

Hardly.

What Obama did not mention was that in 1959, preparatory to its invasion of South Vietnam, North Vietnam invaded Laos in order to establish a major segment of the Ho Chi Minh Trail bringing weapons, supplies, and manpower from North to South. North Vietnam also sponsored and supported with its own troops a Communist insurgency, the Pathet Lao, to overthrow the Royal Government of Laos. The U.S. responded to this Communist aggression -- conducted in violation of the Geneva Accords of 1954 and 1962 -- by providing covert and overt aid to the government of Laos and to Hmong militias who were fighting the Communists. Unlike in South Vietnam, the U.S. did not send combat troops to Laos; instead it relied on the CIA and the Special Forces to fight a "secret war" utilizing Laotians who were determined to resist Communist domination. The most capable American-supported leader was Vang Pao, a Hmong tribesman who was a general in the Lao army. Eventually he led as many as 40,000 guerrillas fighting the Pathet Lao and the North Vietnamese Army.

The U.S. bombing of Laos was conducted in support of Vang Pao and other anti-Communist fighters and as part of a general effort to disrupt the Ho Chi Minh Trail -- the logistics line that enabled aggression against a sovereign state allied with the United States. Those interested in learning more should read my colleague Joshua Kurlantzick's excellent forthcoming book A Great Place to Have a War: America in Laos and the Birth of a Military CIA (out in January from Simon & Schuster).

It is certainly possible to question the utility and even the morality of U.S. bombing in Laos -- but it is highly misleading for any analyst, much less the president of the United States, to criticize the U.S. in a vacuum without noting the actions of the North Vietnamese and the Pathet Lao who killed countless numbers of Laotian civilians, violated Laotian sovereignty, and ultimately overthrew the internationally recognized government of Laos in order to impose a Communist dictatorship. That dictatorship continues to rule to this day, by the way. It has made some economic reforms primarily to encourage tourism, but it remains a dictatorship that is rated "not free" by Freedom House.

To his credit, Obama did speak out about human rights during his trip although in a particularly mealy-mouthed way. He never directly criticized Laos's human-rights record, which is poor. He never highlighted the plight of dissidents or called for democracy. Instead he spoke in oblique terms about the importance of human rights while making clear that they are not very crucial in the U.S.-Laos relationship: "As we do around the world, the United States will continue to speak up on behalf of what we consider universal human rights, including the rights of the people of Laos to express yourselves freely and decide your own future. Yet even as our governments deal candidly with our differences, I believe, as we have shown from Cuba to Burma to Vietnam, the best way to deliver progress for all of our peoples is by closer cooperation between our countries. And that's why, today, the United States and Laos have agreed to a new comprehensive partnership to guide and deepen our relationship for years to come." In other words, while saying he would speak out on behalf of human rights, Obama did not really do that.

I get what Obama is up to here. He thinks the U.S. can exercise more influence today by acknowledging past "misconduct" without directly criticizing the behavior of countries it deals with. The problem is that, in practice, this amounts to kow-towing to dictators from Cuba to Iran and buying into their fiction that the U.S. is guilty of conduct just as bad, if not worse, than what they have done. That simply isn't true, and by shading the truth the president is failing to speak on behalf of the principles upon which the United States was founded-and which have long been our most powerful tool and selling point in international affairs. He is also inadvertently buttressing the dictatorships he is dealing with; now they can turn to their people and say in essence, "Our problems are America's fault-the president of the United States even said so." What we have seen during the two terms of the Obama presidency is that by failing to speak out more robustly on behalf of freedom, the president is not winning any friends; he is simply convincing the world's dictators that he is a patsy who can be pushed around with impunity.

Donald Trump is many things but subtle isn't one of them. While campaigning in Ohio yesterday, he said that Iran "is going to destroy Israel unless I get elected." But if he wins, "then Israel will be just fine." That's a pretty simple formulation and it's one that some friends of the Jewish state are buying. Are they right?

The basic premise of this apocalyptic argument is that the nuclear deal the Obama administration struck with Iran poses an existential threat to the state of Israel. Trump is right about that. The deal makes an Iranian bomb possible in the long term while also enriching the regime and strengthening its ability to support terror and harass Israel via its Hezbollah auxiliaries and Hamas allies.

The question is, what can Trump do about it? Or at least what would he do that Hillary Clinton won't?

The first advantage Trump has is that he enters the Iran debate with clean hands, having never supported President Obama's goal of rapprochement with Tehran. The same cannot be said of Clinton. No, the deal didn't happen on Clinton's watch and it might not have come to pass had she not been replaced by John Kerry at the State Department since he ardent supporter of Obama's approach on Iran. But she still supported the negotiations and the dismal final result.

Clinton says she will zealously enforce the terms of the deal and has made noises -- while keeping as little daylight between herself and President Obama as possible for the purposes of the campaign -- about getting tougher on Iranian behavior in the region.

In contrast to most of the other Republican presidential candidates, Trump never said he would tear up the deal. He has merely held it up as a terrible negotiation in which the U.S. gave up its goals and got little in return. The assumption is that somehow he will attempt to renegotiate or re-impose sanctions to get better terms. But since America's European allies will never go along with such a scenario, short of war, that isn't going to happen. So other than a more robust rhetorical approach to Iran, it's not clear what functional difference there will be between his Iran policy and that of Clinton.

But for all of his justified criticism of the nuclear deal, the rest of Trump's foreign and Middle East policy hints at a less contentious approach to Iran.

As Trump said in his security-policy speech delivered today in Philadelphia, he will "work with any country" provided they are willing to cooperate in the struggle against ISIS. While specifically eschewing regime change in any country in the region, he said "new friendships and partnerships" would be pursued in "this mission."

What does that mean?

It means that Trump is interested in cooperating with Russia and, since he wants the U.S. to shoulder as little responsibility for Middle East security as possible, he seems just as willing as Obama to allow Vladimir Putin a free hand in Syria and other trouble spots. And because Russia is in business with Iran in their joint effort to preserve the Assad regime in Syria a Trump administration would appear to be pursuing the same strategic goals as Obama. Given Trump's disdain for efforts to overturn the theocratic dictatorship in Tehran and his general opposition to U.S. military interventions, friends of the Jewish state may be forgiven for dismissing all this talk about preventing Israel's destruction as mere rhetoric.

Pro-Israel advocates would do well to be just as skeptical of Clinton's claims as a champion of Israel. We don't know whether Trump would pursue renewed negotiations with the Palestinians or pressure Israel to help him create a peace deal. He is probably less interested, however, in a continuation of the same failed policies pursued by both the Clinton and the Obama administration. But if you're judging the two candidates on their ability to enable Israel to survive the threat from Iran, Trump's case seems less impressive in the context of his advocacy for more "realism" -- a word that has always been synonymous with policies that are hostile to Israeli security. Moreover, Israelis know better than to rest their safety on anything other than their own strength.

Put simply, Trump's goals are mutually exclusive. The U.S. can't abandon the region while simultaneously enhancing Israel's security. And no matter how magical your negotiating skills might be, you can't have better relations with Russia and work with Iran against ISIS while also pursuing a tougher policy against the latter's nuclear program.

Yesterday's CNN/ORC poll was a thunderbolt that hit the Clinton campaign right between the eyes. Not only did the survey have Donald Trump leading Hillary Clinton for the first time in the race, it also showed her surpassing Trump's already historically high negatives. If that wasn't bad enough, 50 percent of those polled expressed confidence in the GOP candidate's trustworthiness and honesty while only 35 percent would say the same for Clinton. If, as I noted, these results are repeated in other polls, it will be seen as a turning point in the race. But figuring out whether this is a harbinger of a reversal or a mere statistical outlier depends on your ideas about who will be voting in November.

As Chuck Todd pointed out on MSNBC's Meet the Press Daily yesterday, CNN's poll should be viewed with skepticism because of the sample on which it is based. The population polled by CNN had four percentage points more voters that identified as Republicans than Democrats. More than half of them were whites without a college degree. If that is what the electorate looks like in November then Trump will be poised to win or at least come close.

But that electorate looks nothing like the one that went to the polls in 2012, when only about a third of voters were whites without college degrees and Democrats enjoyed a clear edge. So if you adjust CNN's results for a population that looks more like 2012, Clinton takes the lead by four points. Such a result would still reflect a marked decline in voter trust for Clinton as the drip-drip-drip of stories that highlight her lies about the email scandal continues. Though she may be dropping in the polls, the demographic advantages that the Democrats have carried into the fall among female, minority, and young voters are still there.

If this kind of argument about sample proportions sounds familiar, it should. As I noted in June, Mitt Romney and his supporters had claimed the 2012 polls showing Barack Obama winning were wrong because the samples were too Democratic. I made the same mistake at the time, reasoning that there was no way the electorate would skew as heavily toward minorities and Democrats as it had in 2008. Romney was wrong and so was I. It turned out that, if anything, the polls had underestimated the number of Democrats who would turn out to vote.

Since then, many on the right have claimed that there were millions of missing conservative white voters who stayed home in 2012 rather than cast an unenthusiastic ballot for a moderate like Romney. There isn't much evidence to support this theory, but in order to imagine a Trump victory you'd need a 2016 turnout model composed of more whites (and with those whites being skewed toward those without a college degree) than the one that re-elected Obama in 2012.

Such a scenario is not impossible. Like most voters this year, Democrats are unenthusiastic about their choices. Clinton hasn't the appeal among minorities that the first African-American president did. If Trump wins white voters by a greater percentage than Romney did and if minority turnout doesn't increase or actually goes down, then the billionaire can win.

This would be historic, but it is also unlikely. It is hard to imagine why the fastest growing demographic sectors (particularly Hispanics) would not continue to increase their share of the vote, especially since animosity for Trump seems to be a stand-in for enthusiasm for Obama as an incentive for minorities to turn out. And since Trump is losing among college-educated whites -- a group Romney won by double digits -- the prospect of the GOP getting a higher share of the white vote requires the miraculous appearance of those missing millions of white working-class voters who have never voted and who may not actually exist.

Both sides dismiss unfavorable polls and laud those who tell them what they want to hear. But unless Trump's presence on the ballot can transform the electorate into something that doesn't seem to exist, his supporters' optimism is unfounded.
